detail.content: Equipment : Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Student Affairs Academic Services Student Life Financial Aid and Scholarships Career Development Counseling Services International Students Incoming Students Graduation Forms & Academic Downloads  home > Student Affairs        Equipment Requirements and Recommendations by Department     Cinema Studies No equipment recommendations       Dance No equipment recommendations       Drama No equipment recommendations       Dramatic Writing No equipment recommendations       Film & Television    For a full listing of required and recommended purchases, please visit: http://www.tisch.nyu.edu/object/UFTV_purchases.html .        Photography & Imaging    Our digital imaging labs are fully equipped with Mac Pro desktops, color calibrated monitors, high-end scanners and inkjet printers, and are available for use by all Photography & Imaging majors. However, it is always helpful for students to have their own computers to use outside of lab hours and for word processing, messaging and personal work, for which our labs are not equipped. Software and Apple products should be purchased from the NYU Computer Store, which provides a higher discount than online educational discounts.    More advanced equipment should probably be purchased after the student gets a sense of his/her workflow and what his/her needs and interests really are, rather than buying something expensive and useful but personally irrelevant.    Additional memory may be purchased for less at http://www.macsales.com or http://www.crucial.com. External firewire devices and other peripherals may be purchased through http://www.macsales.com or http://www.newegg.com or other dealers.    Computers:       15” laptops are recommended for portability. If buying new, a MacBook Pro is preferable to a MacBook for the added processing power in dealing with large imaging files. Our recommended, discounted laptop package is available at the NYU Computer Store. The computer should include:       Airport wireless card    At least 300GB internal hard drive    OS 10.5+ operating system    Superdrive (writes to DVDs)    At least 4GB RAM    Helpful but optional additions include:       A faster graphics processing card if video editing is of interestd    Additional RAM (up to 8GB recommended)    Peripherals       Students should own a portable hard drive for storing and transferring large files. Students with iPods should be warned that iPods are less reliable for transferring data than ordinary hard drives and the department does not provide compatible cables.    Hard drives should:       Be at least 250GB    Have Firewire 400 and 800 ports    Have at least a 1-year warranty    Preferably be 7200 rpm    Students interested in working with video should purchase a full-sized external hard drive of at least 500GB at 7200rpm from a reliable manufacturer (G-Technologies, Western Digital, Seagate, OWC, et al.)    Other recommended peripherals include:       3-button mouse    slender carrying case    Software       Adobe Creative Suite 5 Design Premium (student licensing is available at the NYU Computer Store)    Microsoft Office 2008 for Mac (student licensing available at NYU Computer Store)    Symantec virus software (available as a free download from NYU Home)       Please refer to http://photo.tisch.nyu.edu/object/pi_software.html for a list of software available in our digital labs.    Cameras    All students must have a 35mm SLR with manual controls OR a Digital SLR (DSLR) to enter the program, and it is even better to have both.    If you don’t have either, here are a few recommendations:       Film cameras:       Nikon F100 (about $800, new)    Nikon FM10 (about $320, new)    Canon Elan 7NE (about $250 used)    Canon EOS 3 (about $350 used)    Pentax K1000 (about $220 used)    Digital cameras:       Nikon D90, 12.3 Megapixel, (about $1,160)    Canon Digital Rebel T2i 18 Megapixel, (about $800)    Canon 50D 15.1 Megapixel, (about $1,430)    Canon 7D (body only) 18 Megapixel + HD video (about $1,700)    For lenses, we recommend fixed focal length models (like a 50mm f/1.8) rather than the wide to telephoto zoom lenses that are typically packaged with cameras. This is because less expensive zoom lenses are usually slow and of poor quality – even if they’re made by Nikon or Canon.    Any of the cameras mentioned above are fine, as are many others by these and other manufacturers. The advantage to having a Nikon or Canon camera is that we have a number of lenses that fit these brands, available for students to checkout on a short-term basis.     Also, for those who already have either a film or digital camera and are looking at getting the other, sticking to the same brand can often save money if the lenses are compatible.    The prices for both the 35mm SLR’s and DSLR’s are from B&H, (http://www.bhphotovideo.com/) a large camera store here in New York City.       Recorded Music For a full listing of required and recommended purchases, please visit: http://clivedavisdept.tisch.nyu.edu/object/remutechrequirements.html  NYU Computer Store           Undergraduate Admissions Graduate Admissions Academic Services Student Life Financial Aid and Scholarships Career Development Counseling Services International Students Incoming Students Graduation Forms What is Special Programs?                  Enrollment, Retention and Graduation Statistics                                                  Byline : Published Work                                            Equipment Resources and Information                Wireless Network Access ("WiFi") at NYU Journalism   The journalism department uses the NYURoam wireless service , which is available at more than 100 locations on the NYU campus. After setup, you'll be able to use NYURoam anywhere else it's offered without having to reconfigure or adjust anything.   The ITS website offers extensive information on getting going:   Computer Requirements   How to Set Things Up   Available Locations   Workshops and Other Help   Please keep in mind that the service is run and supported by ITS, not the journalism department, so if you have any issues you'll need to contact them .   Field Equipment Policy   The department's currently stated policy governing the lending of field equipment to those qualified (by virtue of course enrollment) to borrow video/audio gear. Please review this information carefully - you will be held accountable for all borrowed equipment based on the dictates of this policy.   Institute Guidelines for Field Equipment Purchases   The NYU Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute provides guidelines for students interested in purchasing their own field equipment.  All the items on this list are compatible with the equipment that the Institute currently checks out to students.  The list will be updated periodically.                                            Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute New York University        20 Cooper Square, 6th Floor New York, NY 10003 212-998-7980                                                          Current Students Links                  NYU Journalism Ethics Pledge (PDF) >          NYU Journalism Ethics Handbook (PDF) >          NYU Journalism Ethics Web Page >          Equipment Policy >                               Course Listings                  Fall 2015 >          Summer 2015 >          Spring 2015 >          Fall 2014 >          Summer 2014 >          Spring 2014 >                               Career Services                  Job and Internship Listings >          Credit Internship Courses >                 Technical Issues         journalism.webmaster@nyu.edu         Funding for this site was generously provided by Ted Cohen and Laura Foti Cohen (WSC '78)                               © Copyright 2015 NYU

Equipment signups allow individuals to schedule a date and time for use of particular equipment. In order to use the online scheduling system, a kerberos id and password are required.                             3rd Floor Fluorometer           9800XL Flatbed Scanner           Amaxa Nucleofector           Animal facility two photon microscope           ArtixScan Slide And Negative Scanner           Biorad Two Photon Microscope           BOC Edward Auto 306 Evaporator           CM12 Electron Microscope           CM200 FEG           Dustin Lab Nikon TIRF           Dustin Lab Olympus TIRF           Gan Lab Biorad Confocal Microscope           Inverted Confocal Microscope           Lehmann Lab Confocal                   Lehmann Lab Two Photon Microscope           Leica SP5 confocal           Leica UCT           Microscopy Core - Zeiss LSM 510           OCS IVIS           Poster Schedule           Skirball 3rd Floor Small Meeting Room           Skirball MRI           Skirball Roche LC480 qPCR Machine           Skirball Ultrasound 1           Zeiss 510 Confocal - Burden Lab           Zeiss 700 Confocal - 5th Floor           Zeiss 710 Confocal and Multiphoton           Zeiss Axioplan Microscope                                              Call us for more information: 212-263-2989       NYULMC Home   Contact Us   For Faculty & Staff   Careers   Make a Gift   Site Map

This is because less expensive zoom lenses are usually slow and of poor quality – even if they’re made by Nikon or Canon.    Any of the cameras mentioned above are fine, as are many others by these and other manufacturers. The advantage to having a Nikon or Canon camera is that we have a number of lenses that fit these brands, available for students to checkout on a short-term basis.     Also, for those who already have either a film or digital camera and are looking at getting the other, sticking to the same brand can often save money if the lenses are compatible.    The prices for both the 35mm SLR’s and DSLR’s are from B&H, (http://www.bhphotovideo.com/) a large camera store here in New York City. Equipment : Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Student Affairs Academic Services Student Life Financial Aid and Scholarships Career Development Counseling Services International Students Incoming Students Graduation Forms & Academic Downloads  home > Student Affairs        Equipment Requirements and Recommendations by Department     Cinema Studies No equipment recommendations       Dance No equipment recommendations       Drama No equipment recommendations       Dramatic Writing No equipment recommendations       Film & Television    For a full listing of required and recommended purchases, please visit: http://www.tisch.nyu.edu/object/UFTV_purchases.html .        Photography & Imaging    Our digital imaging labs are fully equipped with Mac Pro desktops, color calibrated monitors, high-end scanners and inkjet printers, and are available for use by all Photography & Imaging majors. However, it is always helpful for students to have their own computers to use outside of lab hours and for word processing, messaging and personal work, for which our labs are not equipped. Software and Apple products should be purchased from the NYU Computer Store, which provides a higher discount than online educational discounts.    More advanced equipment should probably be purchased after the student gets a sense of his/her workflow and what his/her needs and interests really are, rather than buying something expensive and useful but personally irrelevant.    Additional memory may be purchased for less at http://www.macsales.com or http://www.crucial.com. External firewire devices and other peripherals may be purchased through http://www.macsales.com or http://www.newegg.com or other dealers.    Computers:       15” laptops are recommended for portability. If buying new, a MacBook Pro is preferable to a MacBook for the added processing power in dealing with large imaging files. Our recommended, discounted laptop package is available at the NYU Computer Store. The computer should include:       Airport wireless card    At least 300GB internal hard drive    OS 10.5+ operating system    Superdrive (writes to DVDs)    At least 4GB RAM    Helpful but optional additions include:       A faster graphics processing card if video editing is of interestd    Additional RAM (up to 8GB recommended)    Peripherals       Students should own a portable hard drive for storing and transferring large files. Students with iPods should be warned that iPods are less reliable for transferring data than ordinary hard drives and the department does not provide compatible cables.    Hard drives should:       Be at least 250GB    Have Firewire 400 and 800 ports    Have at least a 1-year warranty    Preferably be 7200 rpm    Students interested in working with video should purchase a full-sized external hard drive of at least 500GB at 7200rpm from a reliable manufacturer (G-Technologies, Western Digital, Seagate, OWC, et al.)    Other recommended peripherals include:       3-button mouse    slender carrying case    Software       Adobe Creative Suite 5 Design Premium (student licensing is available at the NYU Computer Store)    Microsoft Office 2008 for Mac (student licensing available at NYU Computer Store)    Symantec virus software (available as a free download from NYU Home)       Please refer to http://photo.tisch.nyu.edu/object/pi_software.html for a list of software available in our digital labs.    Cameras    All students must have a 35mm SLR with manual controls OR a Digital SLR (DSLR) to enter the program, and it is even better to have both.    If you don’t have either, here are a few recommendations:       Film cameras:       Nikon F100 (about $800, new)    Nikon FM10 (about $320, new)    Canon Elan 7NE (about $250 used)    Canon EOS 3 (about $350 used)    Pentax K1000 (about $220 used)    Digital cameras:       Nikon D90, 12.3 Megapixel, (about $1,160)    Canon Digital Rebel T2i 18 Megapixel, (about $800)    Canon 50D 15.1 Megapixel, (about $1,430)    Canon 7D (body only) 18 Megapixel + HD video (about $1,700)    For lenses, we recommend fixed focal length models (like a 50mm f/1.8) rather than the wide to telephoto zoom lenses that are typically packaged with cameras. This is because less expensive zoom lenses are usually slow and of poor quality – even if they’re made by Nikon or Canon.    Any of the cameras mentioned above are fine, as are many others by these and other manufacturers. The advantage to having a Nikon or Canon camera is that we have a number of lenses that fit these brands, available for students to checkout on a short-term basis.     Also, for those who already have either a film or digital camera and are looking at getting the other, sticking to the same brand can often save money if the lenses are compatible.    The prices for both the 35mm SLR’s and DSLR’s are from B&H, (http://www.bhphotovideo.com/) a large camera store here in New York City. and Information                Wireless Network Access ("WiFi") at NYU Journalism   The journalism department uses the NYURoam wireless service , which is available at more than 100 locations on the NYU campus. After setup, you'll be able to use NYURoam anywhere else it's offered without having to reconfigure or adjust anything.   The ITS website offers extensive information on getting going:   Computer Requirements   How to Set Things Up   Available Locations   Workshops and Other Help   Please keep in mind that the service is run and supported by ITS, not the journalism department, so if you have any issues you'll need to contact them .   Field Equipment Policy   The department's currently stated policy governing the lending of field equipment to those qualified (by virtue of course enrollment) to borrow video/audio gear. Please review this information carefully - you will be held accountable for all borrowed equipment based on the dictates of this policy.   Institute Guidelines for Field Equipment Purchases   The NYU Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute provides guidelines for students interested in purchasing their own field equipment.  All the items on this list are compatible with the equipment that the Institute currently checks out to students.  The list will be updated periodically.                                            Arthur L.
